title: Angola Education — Schools, Universities & Student Guide
content:
The education system in Angola is a complex and evolving structure that offers a range of opportunities for students, from primary education to higher learning, with both public and private institutions available.

[SECTION] Education System Overview [/SECTION]
The education system in Angola is divided into three main stages: primary, secondary, and tertiary education. Primary education, also known as **ensino primário**, is compulsory for all children between the ages of 6 and 11 and lasts for 6 years. Secondary education, or **ensino secundário**, is divided into two cycles: the first cycle lasts for 2 years and the second cycle lasts for 3 years. Tertiary education, or **ensino superior**, includes universities and polytechnic institutions, and offers a range of undergraduate and graduate degree programs. The quality of education in Angola varies, with public schools often facing challenges such as limited resources and outdated infrastructure, while private schools tend to offer higher quality education but at a higher cost.

The public education system in Angola is free and compulsory for all children, but the quality of education can vary greatly depending on the region and the school. Private schools, on the other hand, offer a range of educational programs and are often preferred by families who can afford the tuition fees. Despite the challenges facing the education system, the Angolan government has made efforts to improve the quality of education, including investing in teacher training and infrastructure development.

The education system in Angola also faces challenges such as a shortage of qualified teachers, particularly in rural areas, and a lack of resources and infrastructure. However, the government has made efforts to address these challenges, including implementing programs to attract and retain qualified teachers and investing in the development of new schools and educational facilities.

[SECTION] International Schools [/SECTION]
- International schools in Angola offer a range of curricula, including the **International Baccalaureate (IB)**, the British curriculum, and the American curriculum.
- The **Luanda International School** is one of the most well-known international schools in the country, offering a range of educational programs for students from preschool to grade 12.
- The **Angolan British School** offers a British-style education, with a focus on English language and literature, mathematics, and science.
- International schools in Angola can be expensive, with tuition fees ranging from $5,000 to $15,000 per year.
- Many international schools are located in Luanda, the capital city, but there are also schools in other major cities, such as Benguela and Huambo.

[SECTION] Studying as a Foreigner [/SECTION]
- To study in Angola, foreign students must obtain a **student visa**, which can be obtained through the Angolan embassy or consulate in their home country.
- Foreign students must also demonstrate proficiency in **Portuguese**, the official language of Angola, although some universities offer programs in English.
- **Scholarships** are available for foreign students, particularly those from Portuguese-speaking countries, through programs such as the **Bolsa de Estudos do Governo Angolano**.
- The cost of living in Angola can be high, particularly in Luanda, where accommodation and food prices are relatively expensive.
- Foreign students must also register with the **Ministério da Educação** and obtain a **cartão de estudante**, a student card that provides access to university facilities and services.
- Health insurance is also required for foreign students, and can be obtained through a range of providers, including the **Angolan National Health Service**.

[SECTION] Education Quality & Challenges [/SECTION]
- One of the major challenges facing the education system in Angola is the **shortage of qualified teachers**, particularly in rural areas.
- The education system also faces challenges related to **infrastructure**, including a lack of classrooms, libraries, and other educational facilities.
- Despite these challenges, the Angolan government has made efforts to improve the quality of education, including **investing in teacher training** and **developing new educational programs**.
- The education system in Angola also faces challenges related to **access and equity**, with many students in rural areas lacking access to quality educational opportunities.
- Recent reforms, such as the introduction of a **new curriculum**, aim to address some of these challenges and improve the overall quality of education in Angola.
